title: Veepstakes 2020: Which Democrats Are Secretly Running for Second Place?
text:
There are more than six months of Democratic debates to endure before we get a proper sense of who will be left standing, so let’s make it more bearable and pretend we’re thinking about vice presidential maneuvering. After all, lots of the Democrats are doing the opposite: pretending they’re not thinking about vice presidential maneuvering. But keeping your second-choice options open is crucial, and lots of Democrats are working hard to do just that.

While offering voters another round of Joe Biden as vice president would be funny, Biden wouldn’t think so, so we can rule that out. We can also rule out Bernie Sanders, who is too old and independent to line up like a party soldier. But just about everyone else, Elizabeth Warren included, would at least consider a number-two spot on the ticket, and some might even be hoping for it. So let’s look at the consolation prize calculations for the non-Biden and non-Sanders candidates.

Elizabeth Warren

If her present momentum is maintained, Warren will herself be the nominee, but she’s still playing it safe. Does Sanders need a running mate? Warren has placed herself as much in his corner as possible without committing to a lot of it. Does Biden need a running mate? Hey, Medicare for All is nice, but “I support a lot of plans.… This isn’t some kind of contest.” As for differences between Biden and Sanders, let Joe and Bernie duke it out. Warren is ready to stand aside and vault past them both, or to join the winner once one of the two is knocked out. She’s kept things vague enough that she can join Bernie’s program or Joe’s depending on the wind, to which she has high insensitivity. If she fails to make the presidential or vice presidential cut, Warren also has more options. Several years ago, people were suggesting she be named Treasury secretary, an idea Warren called a “fun thought.”

Kamala Harris

By tradition, veeps play bad cop on the campaign trail, launching the nastier attacks while the presidential nominee sways above it all. (Donald Trump reversed this tradition, allowing Mike Pence to stay amicable while Trump stayed obnoxious and thus in his element, but Trump’s approach doesn’t demand the same of his opponents.) Cue Kamala Harris, who is combative, elastic, and calculating—in short, perfectly vice presidential. She practices her attacks thoroughly, and, on the likability front, she isn’t at risk of outdoing anyone. She would be appealing to Biden, because, given the zeitgeist, an old white male nominee will face pressure to pick someone younger, female, and nonwhite as a running mate. Since Harris has also attacked Biden for racial sensitivity, she has the power to grant him implicit absolution. If she didn’t get picked as vice president, Harris could be confirmed as attorney general without much trouble. Still, she likes her job in the Senate too much to make that a likely possibility.

Pete Buttigieg

Buttigieg beats Harris in the polls now, and he’s a fine politician, but he doesn’t bring seasoning, so he’d be low on the list for Warren or Harris. He also doesn’t bring economic leftism or racial or gender diversity, so he’d be out of the running for Sanders. His best hope would be that Biden got the nomination and wanted to send a strong message of centrism and youth and implicit indifference to identity. But if picking Buttigieg would help win over wavering white male (and LGBTQ) voters, it would entail a loss of enthusiasm from many nonwhite, non-male voters. It would also cue a thousand “slap in the face” headlines, something no one wants to read, including those writing them.
description: Bernie’s a loner and Warren wants to win, but Kamala, Pete, and Booker might be playing for the consolation prize.
